pullRequest.body:
We prove Proposition 1.3.2/1 from S. Bosch, U. G√ºntzer, R. Remmert, *Non-Archimedean Analysis*: if `f` is a nonarchimedean seminorm on `R`, then `iInf (fun n : PNat => (f (x ^ (n : ‚Ñï))) ^ (1 / (n : ‚Ñù)))` is a power-multiplicative nonarchimedean seminorm on `R`.

---

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ isNonarchimedean_smoothingFun`
`+ isPowMul_smoothingFun`

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

Haven't looked at the mathematics, but here's style and naming comments
Haven't looked at the mathematics, but here's style and naming comments
I have started a review, and stopped at `section IsNonarchimedean` of `SmoothingSeminorm.lean`.
I left some other comment.

One minor comment. Otherwise LGTM

bors d+

Thanks :tada:

bors merge

I would write (untested):
```suggestion
    (hx : ‚àÄ y : R, f (x * y) = f x * f y) (n : ‚Ñï) (y : R) : f (x ^ n * y) = f x ^ n * f y := by
  induction n generalizing y with
  | zero => rw [pow_zero, pow_zero, one_mul, one_mul]
  | succ n hn => rw [pow_succ', pow_succ', mul_assoc, mul_assoc, hx, hn]
```
I tested your suggestion, but it does not work.

```suggestion
open Filter Nat Real
open scoped Topology NNReal
```

```suggestion
variable {R : Type*} [CommRing R] (f : RingSeminorm R)
```

```suggestion
  `f (x ^ (m : ‚Ñï)) ^ (1 / m : ‚Ñù) < iInf (fun n : PNat => (f(x ^(n : ‚Ñï)))^(1/(n : ‚Ñù))) + Œµ/2`. -/
```

```suggestion
  have h0 (n : ‚Ñï) (hn : 1 ‚â§ n) : f (x ^ n) ^ (1 / (n : ‚Ñù)) = 0 := by
```

Maybe
```suggestion
theorem tendsto_smoothingSeminorm'_of_ne_zero (hf1 : f 1 ‚â§ 1) {x : R} (hx : f x ‚â† 0) :
```

```suggestion
theorem tendsto_smoothingSeminorm'_of_eq_zero {x : R} (hx : f x = 0) :
```

```suggestion
theorem tendsto_smoothingSeminorm' (hf1 : f 1 ‚â§ 1) (x : R) :
```

```suggestion
/-- For any `x` and any positive `n`, `smoothingSeminorm' f x ‚â§ f (x^(n : ‚Ñï))^(1/n : ‚Ñù)`. -/
```

I think this fits and splits more sensibly:
```suggestion
    BddBelow
      {a : ‚Ñù |
        ‚àÄ·∂† n : ‚Ñù in map (fun n : ‚Ñï => f x ^ (‚Üë(s (œà n)) * (1 / (œà n : ‚Ñù)))) atTop, n ‚â§ a} := by
```

What about
```
BddBelow {a : ‚Ñù | 
      ‚àÄ·∂† n : ‚Ñù in map (fun n : ‚Ñï => f x ^ (‚Üë(s (œà n)) * (1 / (œà n : ‚Ñù)))) atTop, n ‚â§ a} := by
``` 
instead?
Similar here
In this case, the second line would not fit.
Please check if you used `isLimit` anywhere else

```suggestion
        exact Tendsto.num (tendsto_natCast_atTop_atTop.comp hœà_mono.tendsto_atTop) ha_pos hœà_lim
```

:eyes: 

Can we find a way to make this more readable?
I could split it into `applys`, but I suspect that if I do that I will be asked to golf it again.

```suggestion
theorem isNonarchimedean_smoothingSeminorm' (hf1 : f 1 ‚â§ 1) (hna : IsNonarchimedean f) :
```
Optional: is it worth splitting out these fields as lemmas about `smoothingSeminorm'`?
My impression from related PRs is that this would be discouraged.
What does this name mean?
I suspect this was at some point renamed by mistake. I have changed it to `smoothingSeminorm_map_one_le_one`.

```suggestion
theorem isPowMul_smoothingSeminorm' (hf1 : f 1 ‚â§ 1) : IsPowMul (smoothingSeminorm' f) := by
```
What does `powMul` mean? Maybe `_of_map_pow` (and again this is about the primed definition)
`powMul` denotes that `x` is power-multiplicative with respect to `f`.
Same about `is_mul`
Renamed to `smoothingSeminorm'_apply_of_isMul`.
This uses `of_mul` for the same hypothesis you called `of_is_mul` earlier, right?
Renamed to `smoothingSeminorm'_of_isMul`.

```suggestion
theorem pow_isMul_of_isMul {R : Type*} [MonoidWithZero R] {f : R ‚Üí ‚Ñù} {x : R}
```
The result holds in greater generality.

It would be interesting to have this accept a `@[to_additive]` tag, since the following works:
```
-- theorem fae {R : Type*} [CommRing R] (f : R ‚Üí ‚Ñù) {x : R}
--     (hx : ‚àÄ y : R, f (x + y) = f x + f y) : ‚àÄ (n : ‚Ñï) (y : R), f (n * x + y) = n * f x + f y := by
--   intro n
--   induction n with
--   | zero => intro y; rw [Nat.cast_zero, zero_mul, Nat.cast_zero, zero_mul, zero_add, zero_add]
--   | succ n hn => intro y; rw [Nat.cast_succ, Nat.cast_succ, 
--     add_mul, one_mul, add_mul, one_mul, add_assoc, hn (x + y), hx, ‚Üê add_assoc]
```
but the proof is slightly different and cannot be stupidly ported.
Do you think this could be done in a different PR?
Sure!

```suggestion
nonarchimedean seminorm on a commutative ring `R`, then
`iInf (fun (n : pnat), (f(x ^ (n : ‚Ñï))) ^ (1 / (n : ‚Ñù)))` is a power-multiplicative nonarchimedean seminorm on `R`.
```

```suggestion
* `smoothingSeminorm'` : the iInf of the sequence `n ‚Ü¶ f(x^(n : ‚Ñï)))^(1/(n : ‚Ñù)`.
```
This is really minor: but what about changing `f` to something that remembers a norm, like `ŒΩ` or `Œº`?
I renamed `f` to  `Œº`.
The statement only says it is bounded below; do you want to add a lemma saying that the bound is `0`?
I only need that it is bounded below, but I could add that lemma if you think it would be helpful.
Yes, this might be a good idea.

```suggestion
/-- The iInf of the sequence `n ‚Ü¶ f(x ^ (n : ‚Ñï))) ^ (1 / (n : ‚Ñù)`. -/
```
Why the prime?
I want to save `smoothingSeminorm` for the `RingSeminorm` defined in line 487, so I am using `smoothingSeminorm'` to denote the underlying function.

Oh well, but in this case I guess that you should call it `smoothingFun` or something like this (perhaps `smoothingAsFun` or `FunLikeSmoothing`?). The `'`we normally use for a "modified" version of the main gadget, and I think that users/readers would be confused.
OK, I can use `smoothingFun` for this.

```suggestion
  simpa only [hL0, smoothingSeminormSeq, smoothingSeminorm'] using 
    tendsto_atTop_of_eventually_const h0
```
It seems to me that `smoothingSeminorm' ` should rather be an `abbrev`, that would permit to get rid of all this `simp only`'s, being more reducible.
I have turned both `smoothingFun` and `smoothingSeminormSeq` intro abbrevs. This allowed me to remove some of the simp onlys, but not all of them.

```suggestion
      rwa [tsub_lt_iff_left hL_le]
```
Do we really want the `_m` at the end of the name?

I have renamed this to `smoothingSeminormSeq_exists_pnat`. To be honest, I do not know what would be a good name for this theorem, but since it is private I did not think the naming was too problematic.
Can you add a bit of explanation for this long proof?
I have added comments inside the proof.

```suggestion
theorem tendsto_smoothingSeminorm'_of_le_one (hf1 : f 1 ‚â§ 1) (x : R) :
```
How about `tendsto_smoothingFun_of_map_one_le_one`?
Sounds good!
A prime in `smoothingSeminorm` is lacking (which brings me back at the question about its existence).

```suggestion
  simpa only [eventually_atTop, ge_iff_le] using ‚ü®1, fun _ _ ‚Ü¶ rpow_nonneg (apply_nonneg f _) _‚ü©
```
Ditto about `'`

```suggestion
/-- For any `x` and any positive `n`, `smoothingSeminorm' f x ‚â§ f (x ^ (n : ‚Ñï)) ^ (1 / n : ‚Ñù)`. -/
```

```suggestion
theorem smoothingSeminorm_le (x : R) (n : PNat) :
```

```suggestion
theorem smoothingSeminorm_le_self (x : R) : smoothingSeminorm' f x ‚â§ f x := by
```

```suggestion
  apply (smoothingSeminorm_le_term f x 1).trans
```

```suggestion
    /- We combine the previous steps to deduce that
    `Œº (x ^ (‚Üëm1 * (n / ‚Üëm1) + n % ‚Üëm1)) ^ (1 / ‚Üën) < L + Œµ`. -/
```
Why don't you itnroduce `hn` as a `variable` so that you can remove it from the lemmas below?

```suggestion
  simpa only [mu, ‚Üê Nat.lt_succ_iff] using (Classical.choose_spec (hn n)).1
```

```suggestion
  ¬∑ rw [div_le_one (cast_pos.mpr (Nat.pos_of_ne_zero hn0)), cast_le]
    exact mu_le ..
```

```suggestion
  have hœà : ‚àÄ n, 0 ‚â§ 1 / (œà n : ‚Ñù) := fun _ ‚Ü¶ by simp only [one_div, inv_nonneg, cast_nonneg]
```

```suggestion
  simp [one_div, Set.mem_range, Subtype.exists, Set.mem_univ, exists_const]
```
I can change it, but could you explain why you prefer this?

Because while non-terminal `simp`s should always be `simp only` to avoid breaking the proof downwards, a terminal `simp` will not be broken by the list of `simp` lemmas being added, and there was a discussion here
https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/287929-mathlib4/topic/request.3A.20discourage.20squeezing.20terminal.20simps.3F

I forgot that this also applies to `simpa`, and I suggested a lot of `simpa only [...] using ...`: can you rever those to `simpa [...] using ...` removing the `only`? Sorry for the fuzz.
Done, except for the `simpa only` at line 108 (which breaks if I remove the `only`).

```suggestion
  have hœà_lim' : Tendsto œà atTop atTop := StrictMono.tendsto_atTop hœà_mono
```
Can you move this `private theorem` up, to stay with the others?

```suggestion
      Œº ((x + y) ^ (n : ‚Ñï)) ^ (1 / (n : ‚Ñù)) ‚â§ (Œº (x ^ m) * Œº (y ^ (n - m : ‚Ñï))) ^ (1 / (n : ‚Ñù)) :=
```

```suggestion
  let mu : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñï := fun n => mu Œº hn n
```
This line seems to be longer than 100 chars, no?
It is exactly 100 chars.
I can shorten it a bit by removing the type of `n`.
It should be my VSCode then (I hope you had not actually _counted_ them). Yes, removing the type seems a good idea.
I used regular expression search in VSCode to search for `.{100}`. In any case, I think a linter would complain if it were over 100 chars (but I removed the type anyways).
The proof is quite long, can you comment it a little bit, either before or inline?
I have added some inline comments.
Thanks!

```suggestion
  simpa only [PNat.mk_coe, hnu, ‚Üê mul_rpow (apply_nonneg Œº _) (apply_nonneg Œº _)] using 
    mu_property Œº hn (œà N)
```

```suggestion
/-- If `Œº 1 ‚â§ 1` and `Œº` is nonarchimedean, then `smoothingSeminorm Œº 1 ‚â§ 1`. -/
```
Although this does not reflect the code verbatim, I think it is more readable and useful.

```suggestion
  have h_eq (n : ‚Ñï) : smoothingSeminormSeq Œº x (m * n) ^ m = smoothingSeminormSeq Œº (x ^ m) n := by
    have hm' : (m : ‚Ñù) ‚â† 0 := cast_ne_zero.mpr (_root_.ne_of_gt (lt_of_lt_of_le zero_lt_one hm))
    simp only [smoothingSeminormSeq]
```
Oh, simply because the first line seemed to exceed the 100 chars and removing the \forall sign helps with this. Not really serious...
I think maybe my comment was not at the right place - I was asking about why to remove the `simp only` on line 336.
I think I suggested to remove the `intro n` (I think it is not line 336 anymore, right?)

```suggestion
  `smoothingSeminorm Œº x = Œº x`. -/
```

I am a bit sceptical about the name of this theorem (and the same applies for all `is_mul` and `isMul` in the file `SmoothingSeminorm`: we do not have (AFAIK) a `IsMul` class, whereas this naming in inspired from that. I would probably go for `pow_mul_apply_eq_pow_mul`, or something like this.

Oh, actually there is
https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Group/Center.html#IsMulCentral

Is it worth using that API? At any rate I would then replace all names `IsMul` with `IsMulCentral` to be aligned.
I don't see how to use `IsMulCentral` here (there is no map involved in that definition), but I am ok with renaming this lemma to `pow_mul_apply_eq_pow_mul`.
Oh, you're right. Forget about the `IsMul`, please just go ahead with `pow_mul_apply_eq_pow_mul`. Thanks!
See my other comment (in `Basic`) about this `isMul` naming.
Should this be `of_isMul` (and perhaps even something different if you agree with my comment about this naming in the `Basic.lean` file)?

I have renamed this to `smoothingFun_apply_of_map_mul_eq_mul`. However, I am a bit worried that this makes it seem like the map is multiplicative, while the hypothesis is only that `x` is multiplicative with respect to that map.

I agree, but that's perhaps part of life. I am picking a random result, like
[Ideal.finite_setOf_absNorm_eq](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/RingTheory/Ideal/Norm/AbsNorm.html#Ideal.finite_setOf_absNorm_eq)
and its title does not mention all the assumptions... 

I am personally ok with this, but if you've got better suggestions go ahead ;-)

```suggestion
theorem pow_mul_apply_eq_pow_mul {R : Type*} [MonoidWithZero R] (f : R ‚Üí ‚Ñù) {x : R}
    (hx : ‚àÄ y : R, f (x * y) = f x * f y) (n : ‚Ñï) : ‚àÄ (y : R), f (x ^ n * y) = f x ^ n * f y := by
```
then you can drop the `intro n`.

Also, this doesn't use anything about the real numbers, right? So the target of `f` could be any type with a multiplication, I guess. And then it could move to a basic algebra file.
